Yetta Rides
At Rally
A massive rally is planned
this Sunday in the Great Hall.
Levering, 7 to 9 p.m. to promote
Yetta Bronstein's entrance into
the New York gubernatorial race.
Alan Abel, of Things-Will-GoBetta-With-Yetta fame is the
scheduled speaker. Abel led Mrs.
Bronstein in her unsuccessful bid
for the presidency in 1964.
Mrs. Bronstein is 48 years old,
married and has one son. A
dynamic and often outspoken
woman, she originally hails from
the Bronx and has been active
in a number of drives to recognize women as the leaders of
men.
The candidate for the governorship of New York has supported such measures as lowering the voting age to 18, fluoiidation, national bingo, sex education, and stronger government
in her drive for the presidency
last year.
Mrs. Bronstein, whose husband is a cab driver, stated that
"I intend to staff my cabinet
with people who have failed in
life and have learned to live with
it." With this wide appeal it is
doubted by political pundits that
she can lose in New York,
Mrs. Bronstein further expounds on her controversial ideas
in her book, The President I
Almost Was, available in Hawthorne Books for $4.95. Hopkins
Campaign manager, Jim Freedman, looks forward to a large
turnout for the rally.

fields and then decide intelligently. Or if he already has
a career field in mind, life at a university gives him the
opportunity to explore it, and at the same time to broaden
his knowledge of man and the world about him.

brings him the exhilarating experience of discovering
things about the world, about his fellow men, and, indeed, about himself.

thus he discovers true freedom—freedom that breeds
sesponSibility. It is freedom of the highest kind.

leading naturally to the next: this is the university
process. This is the opportunity that awaits the university man."

The close of each academic year leaves many of us
wondering if there is any sensible justification for being
here. In order to discover just such a reason the News.
Letter has researched the very root of the problem.
We have gone to the very foundation of the University
and in its cornerstone found the greatest camp paperback of all time, the Undergraduate Catalog.
•
To ease the anxiety of our general readership,
beset with finals and Viet-nam we reproduce part of a
catalog essay entitled "What is a University?"
I
"Life at a university, for the man who lives it to the
full, thus becomes an endless voyage of exploration.
If uncertain about his life's work, he can explore many
fields and then decide intelligently. Or if he already has
a career field in mind, life at a university gives him the
opportunity to explore it, and at the same time to broaden
his knowledge of man and the world about him.
Life at a university is an endless process of diseovery. Every course, every reading project or research
activity, every association with faculty men and fellow
students, leads the university man to new ideas and
brings him the exhilarating experience of discovering
things about the world, about his fellow men, and, indeed, about himself.
Life at a unversity is an endless exercise in freeNom. The student learns how prejudices—preconceived
notions—can shackle a man and he learns to liberate
himself from their chains. He learns to base his judgsilents on facts, approached with an open mind. And
thus he discovers true freedom—freedom that breeds
sesponSibility. It is freedom of the highest kind.
Exploration, discovery, and freedom, each step
leading naturally to the next: this is the university
process. This is the opportunity that awaits the university man."

world is coming to an end on July third. Doubtless many
